content: The "Marriage Penalty and Family Tax Relief Act of 2001" eliminates the marriage penalty in standard deduction and ensures that no amendment made by the Act will change tax rates under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Marriage Penalty and Family Tax Relief Act of 2001" eliminates the marriage penalty in standard deduction and makes technical amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including adjustments to the dollar amounts for taxable years. The amendments made by the "Marriage Penalty and Family Tax Relief Act of 2001" apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. SEC. 3. PHASEOUT OF MARRIAGE PENALTY IN 15-PERCENT BRACKET. The text discusses the phaseout of the marriage penalty in the 15-percent tax bracket, starting in taxable years after December 31, 2003. Adjustments are made to the tax tables to address inflation and prevent tax increases. The text discusses adjustments to tax tables for inflation, with specific percentage increases for taxable years starting in 2004 onwards. Rounding rules are also specified. The text discusses amendments to tax credits, including the repeal of reduction of refundable tax credits and an increase in the alternative minimum tax exemption amount for joint returns. The text discusses amendments to tax credits, including an increase in the alternative minimum tax exemption amount for joint returns for even-numbered calendar years, with specific dollar amounts set for 2005, 2006, and 2007. Marriage penalty relief for earned income credit is provided by amending the Internal Revenue Code to adjust the earned income amount for joint returns to 110 percent of the applicable amount. Any non-multiple of $10 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code adjusts earned income for joint returns to 110 percent of the applicable amount, with rounding to the nearest multiple of $10. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. SEC. 5. MODIFICATIONS TO CHILD TAX CREDIT. Increase in Per Child Amount for qualifying children of the taxpayer. The child tax credit amount increased from $600 in 2001 and 2002 to $1,000 in 2006 and thereafter. The credit is limited based on the amount of tax for each taxable year. The child tax credit amount increased to $1,000 in 2006 and thereafter, with limitations based on the amount of tax for each taxable year. Amendments were made to sections 24 and 24(d) of the tax code. Amendments were made to various sections of the tax code, including sections 26, 23, 25, and 904, to update the language regarding tax credits. Amendments were made to section 24 of the tax code, including adding a credit for families with 3 or more children and changing the subsection heading to "Paying Social Security Taxes." The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. The amendments made to section 24 of the tax code, including a credit for families with 3 or more children, will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The Act protects Social Security and Medicare trust funds by ensuring that transferred amounts are determined as if the Act had not been enacted.
